dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So what drew you into quantum computing?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think what got me into material science was actually making semiconductors

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: For solar panels. Then, that drew me into new types of technology that used semiconductors with the one that's very popular now is quantum computings. And what about you? What got you interested in quantum sensing?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, I started out doing magnetic resonance, studying things like bone and biomedical magnetic resonance. Ended up playing with spins for a long time and the physics of spins just fascinated me.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So what do you think is a big difference between imaging large biological objects versus sensing very small quantum objects, I guess?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: In a way, it's part of the same continuum. What you're doing is changing the technological platform and you're actually able to probe it more sensitively. The resolution you're able to get is much higher, so you can see smaller signals in a much smaller volume.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: How is the resolution higher?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So it's because the nitrogen-vacancy center is a single defect. So you can actually see a single electron. In normal magnetic resonance, you don't have the sensitivity.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: In order to be sensitive to like a single electron, do you have to be really close to it?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: You have to be close to it. You can detect it optically because if we tried to detect the magnetic moment of the electron, we wouldn't be able to do that because there, the energy is too low compared to thermal energies. But what the diamond system gives you is a natural up conversion in energy. So you can couple into an optical photon, which is then much easier to detect a single optical photon than it is to detect a micro wave.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay, I see.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah. And that's why you're able to do it at room temperature as well.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: What are some of the challenges you face when trying to do quantum sensing with this platform?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: One of the key challenges, I think for all, any quantum technology is really understanding what limits your coherence times. And then the next question that comes up often is how do we make this better? So if I take a single qubit or a single spin, there's a certain limit up to its sensitivity. But if I can take entangled spins, in principle, I could make the system much more sensitive, but it usually comes at a cost 'cause when I entangle something, it's much more sensitive to de-coherence as well.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: In a similar way, but maybe even in the opposite way where we want to figure out how to be as resilient from noise and all the kinds of noise sources.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What are you studying?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I'm studying superconducting qubits that use hybrids, semiconductor, superconductor structures.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, semiconductors, are you introducing new noise sources potentially that might affect the coherence times?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, so the big one is charge noise, 'cause I guess a lot of the superconducting qubits, they have made 'em in such a way that they're insensitive to charge.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly. So when you think of noise, in what way is a noise bad for your system?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I usually think of it like, well, we work with quantum systems.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [Sekhar] Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And those are very sensitive to fluctuations. Yeah. I guess any fluctuations can kick your quantum system either out of the state that it's in to another state.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I think as you said, you know, anything that interferes with my signal is noise, but it can come from different sources. In some ways, the operation of the quantum system itself, as it's sensitive to different physical phenomena, the ones that I don't like, I call noise. The ones I do like, I call signal and that's an artificial definition that I'm making when I choose to build a sensor. One of the challenges we have is, we're trying to figure out if I wanna control it, where is it coming from? I remember we had experiments running in our lab one day and we were running these experiments about 100 megahertz. All of a sudden, we saw these big spikes coming in and we realized we're picking up the local FM stations.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And that was a source of noise, like, it's completely random, but it is still there. And then the other form is very much what is intrinsically within your experiment itself because some of the materials that you have have defects that are coupling into your sensor, into your quantum system and are also producing noise.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: But yeah, the interesting stuff really is where you're picking up the quantum noise intrinsically from whatever.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right, it could give you information if you read it out, about what's happening or you have to find smart ways to suppress it so that you can focus on what you really do care about.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So what are the kind of noise and fluctuations that you're worried about?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So one of the things that we're interested in is looking at, suppose, I want to build an entangled quantum sensor, when I put a number of spins together, in addition to being sensitive to an external field, they're sensitive to each other and they start talking to each other. You don't just see the external spins, you see the fluctuations of all the other spins in your system. So what you wanna do is make sure that they don't interact with each other, but they still stay sensitive to everything else. And there, you could think about the local interactions, the magnetic interactions between the spins as a form of noise. In some ways, it's interfering with what you wanna measure, which is the magnetic field outside the sample.
